inlineContent.text: A unique identifier string
An optional Header View
0 to 3 Buttons
See:
Modules are built and returned in

code: // build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
Let’s examine each of these three values in detail.
A globally unique indentifier is best to avoid conflicts with any internal or pre-built module names.
We recommend using a reverse URL style.
Unique examples:
“com.ticketmaster.seatUpgrades”
“com.nfl.broncosSeating”
“com.myDemoApp.demoModule”
While optional, the Header is the most easily visible component of a Module.
A Header (
) is simply a wrapper around a UIView.
Note that a Module can contain a Header with no Buttons, or Buttons with no Header.
The Header is automatically resized to the width of the user’s phone, so you can only really control the height. This is done by setting an aspect ratio.
The default aspect ratio (3x2) is recommended for visual consistancy.
Build a module with a Red header, using the default aspect ratio (3x2).

code: // build a UIView (with default aspect ratio 3x2)
// build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
The Header inherits it’s aspect ratio from the provided UIView, so by setting the size of the UIView you can alter the aspect ratio of the Header.
Build a module with a Red header, using a custom defined aspect ratio (1x1).

code: // build a UIView (with a defined aspect ratio)
let view = UIView(frame: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 1, height: 1))
// build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
Headers can also be created with a UIImage (as a convenience). The aspect ratio of the Header is inherited from the size of the UIImage.
Build a module with an Image header, aspect ratio is defined by Image size:

code: // build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
While you are welcome to build a Header using any UIView, a helpful Header builder has been provided.
The
can help you quickly build a UIView for presentation.
The header builder supports:
Three lines of custom Text
Gradient overlay (from top-left and bottom-right corners)
UIColor background
UIImage background
MKCoordinateRegion map
QR Code
2D Barcode
Audio/Video Content
Build a module with a Red header, using the Header View builder:

code: // build a UIView (with default aspect ratio 3x2)
// build module with header and buttons

code: // build a UIView with a text, gradient, and image
// build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:

code: // build a UIView with a text, gradient, and image
// build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:

code: // build a UIView with a text, QR code, gradient, and image
// build module with header, but no buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
The video will start playing as soon as the user scrolls down to the module.
Build a module with a Video and Text:

code: // load video from local file or web URL
// build a UIView with a text, QR code, and image
// build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
Buttons (
) are assigned Actions that occur when the button is pressed.
Currently, only two Actions are supported:
open a given webpage inside Tickets SDK (in a webview)
callback to module delegate (inside your app)
Note that a Module can contain a Header with no Buttons, or Buttons with no Header.
If webpage settings are not defined on the
, then when the user presses the button, the callback method on the module delegate will be called:
Build three buttons (with no header):

code: // build module with header and buttons
// this is not called if webpage settings are already defined
// handle in your own code, do not close modal Tickets Listing page
// handle in your own code, but first close modal Tickets Listing page
// open a webpage inside Tickets SDK (webview)

inlineContent.text: Output:
Notice that the handleModuleActionButton delegate method has a completion closure.
This is used to inform Tickets SDK of which behavior you would like when the user presses a Module Button.
Do not close modal Tickets Listing page and handle button in your own code:

code: // handle in your own code, do not close modal Tickets Listing page

inlineContent.text: Close modal Tickets Listing page first, then handle button in your own code:

code: // handle in your own code, but first close modal Tickets Listing page

inlineContent.text: Do not close modal Tickets Listing page, have Tickets SDK open a webpage for you:

code: // open a webpage inside Tickets SDK (webview)

inlineContent.text: Output:
You can provide the Button webpage settings ahead of time instead of waiting for the callback.
Note that is this case, the handleModuleActionButton delegate method will not be called.
Build one button with pre-defined webpage settings (with no header):

code: // build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: Output:
Typically you will want to pass in some state variables to the webpage. For example, maybe which event the user is viewing.
This can be done with URL parameters.
You may also want to pass values securely. For example, the user’s login state (oauth token).
This can be done with
Example:
Build button with pre-defined webpage settings including eventID and user OAuthToken:

code: // build module with header and buttons

inlineContent.text: A few basic modules have already been created for you, see:

abstract.text: configure with background image and 2D barcode code
Method is invoked if user has pressed a button on a custom module, and unique handling is required.
Method is invoked when the user is viewing a specific Event. Client app needs to define an array of custom modules (if any) and return them to the Tickets SDK.
create a module with the given identifier, header, and action buttons
Implementation of Ticketmaster post-purchase functionality such as viewing purchased Events, Tickets, and Barcodes.
configure with map region and annotation
create a custom module to be displayed underneath the user’s list of Tickets on the Tickets listing page
configure with background image and QR code
configure with Audio/Video content (typically a movie file)
